member.name: T:GraphForms.Algorithms.SpanningTree.ISpanningTreeAlgorithm`2
member.summary: Algorithm classes that implement this interface are designed to generate a spanning tree from a connected graph, which is a sub-graph of that graph that connects all its vertices together with a minimal subset of edges.
member.typeparam: The type of vertices in the spanning tree generated by this algorithm.
The type of edges in the spanning tree generated by this algorithm.
member.remarks: Algorithm classes that implement this interface should also be designed to process non-connected graphs and return a graph containing multiple spanning trees, one for each (weakly) connected component of the input graph.

DO NOT CHANGE THE COLOR OF UNLESS NECESSARY.

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Search.AGraphTraversalAlgorithm`2.InternalCompute
member.summary: This function performs the core functions of a graph traversal algorithm, first calling to initialize any needed data, and then attempting to run main traversal computation at the root node (if it's valid), and then restarting it at any nodes that haven't been explored.

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Search.AGraphTraversalAlgorithm`2.ComputeFromRoot(GraphForms.Algorithms.Digraph{`0,`1}.GNode)
member.summary: The implementation of this function should contain the core code for traversing this algorithm's graph starting at the given node and systematically traveling along edges to explore nodes, turning nodes gray as they are being explored and then black after finishing exploring them, and calling the exploration event functions along the way.
member.param: The root node at which the traversal of the graph starts by following its edges to its unexplored neighboring nodes and so on until a dead end is reached.

member.name: P:GraphForms.Algorithms.Search.AGraphTraversalAlgorithm`2.Reversed
member.summary: If true, the graph is traversed from destination nodes to source nodes instead of from source nodes to destination nodes.

member.name: P:GraphForms.Algorithms.Search.AGraphTraversalAlgorithm`2.Directed
member.summary: If false, the graph is traversed from both the source edges and destination edges of each node instead of just one or the other, but still determines which edge list is traversed first on each node.

member.name: P:GraphForms.Algorithms.Search.AGraphTraversalAlgorithm`2.RootOnly
member.summary: If false (the default value), this algorithm continues to traverse its graph after the root node and all nodes reachable from it have been explored, restarting the traversal from the next unexplored node found until all nodes in the graph have been explored.

summary.para: Gets or sets the maximum exploration depth from the root nodes at which the exploration starts.

member.name: M:GraphForms.GraphElement.StackBefore(GraphForms.GraphElement)
member.summary: Stacks this object before , which must be a sibling object (i.e., the two objects must share the same parent, or must both be toplevel objects). The must have the same Z value as this object, otherwise calling this function will have no effect.
member.param: The sibling behind which this object is stacked.
member.returns: false if is not actually a sibling of this object, true otherwise.
member.remarks: By default, all sibling items are stacked by insertion order (i.e., the first item you add is drawn before the next item you add). If two items' Z values are different, then the item with the highest Z value is drawn on top. When the Z values are the same, the insertion order will decide the stacking order.

member.name: T:GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.Tree`1
member.summary: This tree data structure can be used to create a disjoint set forest. It can represent both single element and a set which contains both it and possibly other elements as well in a spaghetti stack structure. It contains fundamental functions for processing sets in the forest, including FindSet and Union.
member.typeparam: The type of data stored in each tree.

remarks.para: See the Wikipedia article on Disjoint-Set Data Structure for details:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disjoint-set_data_structure

member.name: F:GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.Tree`1.Value
member.summary: The instance stored in this single element of a disjoint forest.

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.Tree`1.#ctor(`0)
member.summary: Creates a new tree instance, which initially represents both the single element and the singleton subset of the disjoint forest which contains this element.
member.param: The element to insert into a singleton subset of a disjoint forest.

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.Tree`1.FindSet
member.summary: Finds the subset of the disjoint forest which contains this tree.
member.returns: The element that represents the subset which contains both it and this element.
member.remarks: The element returned could be this tree element itself. This is always the case when this element is in a singleton, a set containing only one element.

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.Tree`1.FindSet(GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.Tree{`0})
member.summary: Finds the subset of the disjoint forest which contains the given element.
member.param: The element used to find its containing subset.
member.returns: The element that represents the subset which contains both it and the given element.

remarks.para: The element returned could be itself. This is always the case when is in a singleton, a set containing only one tree element.
This algorithm also performs path compression when possible for increased efficiency.

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.Tree`1.AreInSameSet(GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.Tree{`0},GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.Tree{`0})
member.summary: Tests whether the two given elements are contained in the same subset of the disjoint forest.
member.param: The first element to test.
The second element to test.
member.returns: True if and are contained in the same subset of the disjoint forest; false if they are in seperate subsets.

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.Tree`1.Union(GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.Tree{`0},GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.Tree{`0})
member.summary: Joins the two subsets of the disjoint forest which contain the given elements into a single subset (if they are not already both contained in the same subset of the disjoint forest).
member.param: The first element or subset to join.
The second element or subset to join.
member.returns: True if subsets containing and are successfully united, or false if the two elements are already in the same subset.
member.remarks: This algorithm performs union by rank for increased efficiency.

member.summary: Resets this algorithm back to its starting point, which causes it to re-initialize before beginning its next iteration.
member.remarks: This function is useful for when the positions of one or more nodes are changed by external code (such as a user dragging them with their mouse) before this algorithm finishes or aborts its layout computation.

member.summary: Shuffles all layout nodes (but not port nodes) in this layout algorithm's to random positions with minimal intersections of their bounding boxes.
member.remarks: The random positions of the nodes are restricted to within the bounding box of this algorithm's , or within this algorithm's if the cluster node is null.

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Layout.LayoutAlgorithm`2.ShuffleNodes(GraphForms.Box2F)
member.summary: Shuffles all layout nodes (but not port nodes) in this layout algorithm's to random positions with minimal intersections of their bounding boxes.
member.param: A rectangle used to restrict the randomly set positions of the layout nodes to within its boundaries.
member.remarks: The random positions of the nodes are restricted to within the bounding box of this algorithm's , or within this algorithm's if the cluster node is null.

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Layout.LayoutAlgorithm`2.InitializeAlgorithm
member.summary: Reimplement this function to initialize any data needed before the algorithm begins its layout computation. This function is called after and whenever the algorithm is reset using .

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Layout.LayoutAlgorithm`2.PerformIteration(System.UInt32)

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Layout.LayoutAlgorithm`2.EndIteration(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Performs all the necessary actions needed to finish a single iteration calculation of this layout algorithm and then calls to run any custom code.
member.param: The current number of iterations that have already occurred in this algorithm's computation.
member.exception: This layout algorithm hasn't started started an iteration yet with the function.

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Layout.LayoutAlgorithm`2.OnEndIteration(System.UInt32,System.Double)
member.summary: Reimplement this function to perform actions and trigger events at the very end of each iteration, after positions of all the layout nodes have been set.

The sum of the distances travelled by each layout node from their positions on the last iteration to their current positions.

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Layout.LayoutAlgorithm`2.InternalCompute
member.summary: Initializes and synchronously runs the layout computation, iterating until is reached, the algorithm is aborted, no layout node has moved beyond , or returns false.

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Layout.LayoutAlgorithm`2.AsyncIterate(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes the layout (if it's just started or has been reset) and asynchronously runs one iteration, and returns whether it was able to run the current iteration. Returns false if has been reached, the algorithm has been aborted, no layout node has moved beyond , or returns false.
member.param: Whether to force this algorithm to start running again if it has finished or has been aborted.
member.returns: true if the iteration is successfully run, or false if the algorithm has finished or has been aborted.

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Layout.LayoutAlgorithm`2.Abort
member.summary: Stop running the algorithm and abort its computation, both synchronously and asychronously.

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Layout.LayoutAlgorithm`2.Reset
member.summary: Resets the algorithm both synchronously and asynchronously, so that it is ready to begin its layout computation again, but only if it is not currently running or aborting.

member.name: P:GraphForms.Algorithms.Layout.LayoutAlgorithm`2.ClusterNode
member.summary: If is actually a sub-graph, then this is the node in the graph superstructure that encloses it.
member.remarks: This node is used to calculate the boundary positions of port nodes based on their angle around the center of its bounding box. This node also affects the positioning each layout node when they are being moved or shuffled by this algorithm.

member.name: P:GraphForms.Algorithms.Layout.LayoutAlgorithm`2.BoundingBox
member.summary: This bounding box is used as a substitute for if it is null.

remarks.para: When this bounding box is used in place of a cluster node, the positions of layout nodes are restricted to inside it when they are being moved and shuffled by this algorithm.
This box is also used in place of the cluster node for calculating the boundary positions of port nodes based on their angle around its center.

member.name: P:GraphForms.Algorithms.Layout.LayoutAlgorithm`2.ItemMoved
member.summary: Whether any nodes changed position during the last iteration. If nodes aren't moving, the algorithm has obviously reached an equilibrium and finished.

member.name: P:GraphForms.Algorithms.Layout.LayoutAlgorithm`2.AsyncState
member.summary: The current state of the asynchronous computation of this layout algorithm.

member.name: P:GraphForms.Algorithms.Layout.LayoutAlgorithm`2.AsyncIterations
member.summary: The current number of asynchronous iterations completed by the asynchronous computation of this layout algorithm.

member.name: P:GraphForms.Algorithms.Layout.LayoutAlgorithm`2.MaxIterations
member.summary: The maximum number of iterations this algorithm is allowed to perform before finishing or aborting its layout computation.

member.name: P:GraphForms.Algorithms.Layout.LayoutAlgorithm`2.MovementTolerance
member.summary: This is the minimum distance squared that a node has have been moved by this layout algorithm or by in order for the node to be considered "moved" on each iteration. If none of the nodes have moved a squared distance greater than this tolerance value, the algorithm stops iterating and finishes.
member.exception: The new tolerance is less than zero.

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Layout.Tree.BalloonTreeLayoutAlgorithm`2.GetBoundingRadius(`0,System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculates the radius of a circle that encloses the given , which is used to calculate the convex hulls of the subtrees that include the given node in their branches.
member.param: The node enclosed within a circle of the returned radius.
The index of the in its graph, which is being processed by this layout algorithm.
member.returns: The radius of the bounding circle of the given , which by default is the smallest circle that circumscribes the given node's bounding box.

remarks.para: This function is only used when the layout algorithm builds its balloon tree data structure, which is only done when its and/or the values of its and/or parameters are changed.

By default, this function simply returns half the length of the diagonal of the given 's , which is the radius of the smallest circle that circumscribes it. It does not compensate for the possibility that the node's "center" might not be the center of its bounding box (the box's might not be equal to - / 2, or its might not be equal to - / 2).

This method can be overridden to take that into account, and/or to provide a more efficient bounding radius calculation for certain nodes. However, be aware that if this function ever returns a value less than or equal to zero, an will be thrown when the layout algorithm attempts to use that invalid radius.

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Layout.Tree.BalloonTreeLayoutAlgorithm`2.CalculateBranchPositions(GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.GTree{`0,`1,GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.CircleGeom{`0,`1}}[])
member.summary: Calculates the polar coordinates (the and ) of each subtree or leaves in the given array of .
member.param: An array of layout node subtrees or leaves that share the same .

remarks.para: For classes that reimplement this function, be aware that this function is invoked recursively from the root down to the leaves of the layout tree, so the polar coordinates of the positions of the of each subtree in the given have already been calculated by a previous invocation of this function, and then the of each subtree was calculated based on those positions.

In general, take great care when reimplementing this function, as it is the most important function of the entire balloon tree layout algorithm. The polar coordinate positions of the given calculated by this function are not only used to calculate the convex hull of their shared , but they are also used to determine the final positions of the layout nodes at their centers.

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Layout.Tree.BalloonTreeLayoutAlgorithm`2.GetMaximumTreeWedge(GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.GTree{`0,`1,GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.CircleGeom{`0,`1}})

summary.para: Gets the maximum allowable wedge in radians that the of the given can occupy around it.
Be aware that this angle will be normalized to the range [0,2] ( [0,360] ) when used.

member.param: The root to get maximum allowable wedge that its branches can occupy around it.
member.returns: The maximum allowable wedge in radians that the branches of the given can occupy around it.
member.remarks:
By default, this function simply returns for the root of the entire balloon tree and for the roots of every subtree in the balloon tree, except when the subtree has exactly two branches. In that case it returns (180) if is greater than that amount (when normalized) in order to make the tree look better. See those properties for further details on what the
function does with the wedge angle this function returns.

Anything that uses this comparer should give meaningful values to its , , and fields before using it to sort of a set of instances that share the same .

member.summary: The X-coordinate of the center of the shared root of x and y.

member.name: F:GraphForms.Algorithms.Layout.Tree.BalloonTreeLayoutAlgorithm`2.SketchSorter.CY
member.summary: The Y-coordinate of the center of the shared root of x and y.

summary.para: The angle in radians measured counterclockwise from the +X-axis of the ray from the center of the shared root of x and y to the center of its own root,
which basically represents the direction of the -X-axis of the local coordinate system of the shared root of x and y.
This is used to make sure that x and y are on the same side of the -X-axis of the local coordinate system of their shared root so that they are correctly compared.

If the shared root of x and y has no root of its own (it is the base root of the entire balloon tree), - (-180) should be used in order to reduce the number of normalization operations performed on the angles of x and y.

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.CircleGeom`2.CalculateConvexHull
member.summary: Forces this circle tree to calculate its and causes all of its branches which have been invalidated to also calculate their convex hulls.

Incremental Algorithms for Finding the Convex Hulls of Circles and the Lower Envelopes of Parabolas
Olivier Devillers, Mordecai J Golin
Information Processing Letters 56 (3), 157-164, 1995
http://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/docs/00/41/31/63/PDF/dg-iafch-95.pdf

member.name: P:GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.CircleGeom`2.Distance
member.summary: The distance between the centers of this circle tree and its . Attempting to set a negative value causes the distance to be set to the inverse value and the to be increased by radians (180).

remarks.para: This value is part of the polar coordinates that define the position of this circle tree.

summary.para: This data structure represents an individual arc in the convex hull of a circle tree instance.
It includes the arc's radius, its polar coordinates around the center of its parent convex hull, and angles that represent its endpoints around its own center.
Unless stated otherwise, all fields that store an angular value are in radians in the range [-,] ( [-180,180] ).

member.name: F:GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.CircleGeom`2.CHArc.Data
member.summary: The of the circle that formed this arc in its convex hull and/or the convex hulls of its ancestors.

member.name: F:GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.CircleGeom`2.CHArc.Rad
member.summary: The radius this arc.

member.name: F:GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.CircleGeom`2.CHArc.Dst
member.summary: The distance between this arc's center and the center of its parent convex hull.

member.name: F:GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.CircleGeom`2.CHArc.Ang
member.summary: The angle of the center of this arc around the center of its parent convex hull, measured in radians counterclockwise from the +X-axis of the local coordinate system of its parent convex hull.

summary.para: The wedge between this arc's lower endpoint and the infinite ray from the center of its parent convex hull through its own center,
measured in radians clockwise from the latter ray around this arc's own center (not the center of its parent convex hull).
The wedge between this arc's upper endpoint and the infinite ray from the center of its parent convex hull through its own center,
measured in radians counterclockwise from the latter ray around this arc's own center (not the center of its parent convex hull).

member.name: F:GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.CircleGeom`2.CHArc.WedgeOffset
member.summary:
The angle between an infinite ray from the center of this arc's parent convex hull through a point intersecting this arc and the ray from the center of this arc's parent convex hull to its own center,
measured in radians counterclockwise from the latter ray around the center of this arc's parent convex hull. Unlike all the other angular fields, this field has a range of [-2,2] ( [-360,360] ) instead of [-,] ( [-180,180] ).

remarks.para: This field is almost always zero, and it is really only used when there are two or more arcs with the same and , but different and values as a result of being split by another arc. In this case, these two new arcs need to be differentiated from each other and have a way being arranged both before and after the arc that split them when sorted by their angle around the center of their parent convex hull.
This is why the arcs that form a convex hull are sorted by the sum of their and this wedge offset, instead of just their , which might not be unique.

This field is not needed when the arc's center is also the center of its parent convex hull (its is zero), as the values of the two new arcs resulting from a split can be set to be centered within their respective wedges.

summary.para: Gets or sets the maximum allowable wedge in radians that the set of subtree/leaf nodes are allowed to occupy around the root node of the entire balloon tree.
Be aware that this angle will be normalized to the range [0,2] ( [0,360] ) when used.

member.remarks: If the sum the bounding wedges of the set of subtree/leaf nodes exceeds this wedge, their s are increased until all their bounding wedges can fit within it. Then their s are set in the range (-wedge / 2, wedge / 2), measured counterclockwise from the +X-axis of their shared root's local coordinate system.

Then their s are set in the range (-wedge / 2, wedge / 2), measured counterclockwise from the +X-axis of their shared root's local coordinate system.

summary.para: This interface represents a special type of virtual node used by layout algorithms to convey positioning information between sub-graphs and their higher graph superstructure.
Beware that some layout algorithms will treat this port nodes differently than they treat nodes.

remarks.para: Instances of classes implementing this interface are typically created when a graph is divided into sub-graphs enclosed within "cluster" nodes in the graph superstructure.

Port nodes essentially represent a node that is outside its sub-graph and connected to one or more nodes in its sub-graph, which could be either a node in another sub-graph or a "cluster" node enclosing another sub-graph in the graph superstructure.

member.name: P:GraphForms.Algorithms.Layout.IPortNode.ClusterId
member.summary: The unique identifier for the node in the graph superstructure that this port node represents, or which contains the node that this port node represents.
member.remarks: This identifier is used by some layout algorithms to make sure that port nodes affiliated with the same cluster node and edge in the graph superstructure are kept close together in their sub-graph instead of possibly ending up on opposite sides of it.

member.name: P:GraphForms.Algorithms.Layout.IPortNode.MinAngle

member.name: P:GraphForms.Algorithms.Layout.IPortNode.MaxAngle
member.summary: The maximum allowable angle of the position of this port node around the center of the bounding box of the cluster node that encloses the sub-graph of this port node.

member.remarks: For more information on Fibonacci Heaps, see the Wikipedia article: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fibonacci_heap

member.name: T:GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.FibonacciNode`2.Heap
member.summary: A Fibonacci Heap data structure that consists of a collection of trees. It is an efficient implementation of a priority queue, which is like a regular queue, but each element also has a "priority" associated with it, and these "priorities" are used to determine the order in which the elements are removed.
member.remarks: For more information on Fibonacci Heaps, see the Wikipedia article: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fibonacci_heap

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.FibonacciNode`2.Heap.UpdateNext
member.summary: Updates the Next pointer, maintaining the heap by folding duplicate heap degrees into each other. Takes O(log(N)) time amortized.

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.FibonacciNode`2.Heap.UpdateNodesDegree(GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.FibonacciNode{`0,`1})
member.summary: Updates the degree of a node, cascading to update the degree of its ancestors if neccesary.
member.param: The node that will have its degree updated (as well as its ancestors if necessary).

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.FibonacciNode`2.Heap.Enqueue(`0,`1)
member.summary: Adds a new element to this Fibonacci Heap, which stores the given with the given , which is used to determine its ordering relative to other elements already in this heap.
member.param: The "priority" of the element, which determines its order in this Fibonacci Heap.
The value stored in the element.
member.returns: A instance that represents the new element added to this Fibonacci Heap.
member.remarks: This operation is done in O(1) time, and it is also fast as well because it does not do any book keeping or maintenance of the heap. It just adds the new element to the end of the list of heaps, updating if necessary (if the new element has the highest/lowest of all the elements in this Fibonacci Heap).

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.FibonacciNode`2.Heap.Peek
member.summary: Returns the next element to be removed from this Fibonacci Heap without removing it, which is the element with the highest (or lowest, depending on the ) out of all the elements in this Fibonacci Heap.
member.returns: The next element to be removed from this Fibonacci Heap, which is the element with the highest/lowest "priority".
member.remarks: This operation is done in O(1) time because all Fibonacci Heaps maintain a pointer to the next element to be removed.

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.FibonacciNode`2.Heap.Dequeue
member.summary: Removes the element currently at the front of this Fibonacci Heap, which is element with the highest (or lowest, depending on the ) "priority".
member.returns: The element that was just removed from this Fibonacci Heap, which was the element with the highest/lowest "priority".

remarks.para: This operation is done in O(log n) amortized time, because it operates in three phases, first removing the element and making its children the roots of new trees in the internal tree list of this Fibonacci Heap, which is done in O(log n) amortized time.
In the second phase, the internal tree list is compressed by successively linking together roots of the same degree, which is done in O(log n) amortized time.
In the final phase, the new element is located among the remaining roots, which is done in O(log n) time, since that's the maximum number of remaining roots at the end of the second phase.

member.exception: This Fibonacci Heap is empty and has no elements to remove.

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.FibonacciNode`2.Heap.Delete(GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.FibonacciNode{`0,`1})
member.summary: Removes the given from this Fibonacci Heap if it hasn't already been removed.
member.param: The instance to be removed from this Fibonacci Heap.
member.remarks: This operation is done in O(log n) amortized time, since it is basically a combination of the and operations. The priority of the given is first set so that it becomes the new element, which takes O(1) amortized time, and then it is removed from this Fibonacci Heap, which takes O(log n) amortized time.
member.exception: is null.

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.FibonacciNode`2.Heap.ChangePriority(GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.FibonacciNode{`0,`1},`0)
member.summary: Sets the of the given to the given , which will affect the order in which affect the order in which is removed from this heap if it hasn't already been removed.
member.param: The instance that will have its priority changed.
The new priority for the given .
member.remarks: This operation is done in O(1) amortized time, since the new for the given could violate the heap property by being out of order with the priority of the parent of , which means that the operation could take longer by having to alter the internal tree list of this Fibonacci Heap.
member.exception: is null.

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.FibonacciNode`2.Heap.Merge(GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.FibonacciNode{`0,`1}.Heap)
member.summary: Merges this Fibonacci Heap with the Fibonacci Heap by concatenating the elements of the other heap with the elements of this Fibonacci Heap.
member.param: The Fibonacci Heap to merge with this heap.
member.remarks: This operation is done in O(1) time because all it does is concatenate the internal list of trees in the Fibonacci Heap with the internal list of trees in this Fibonacci Heap, which is a quick operation since they are doubly linked lists.

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.FibonacciNode`2.Heap.ToArray
member.summary: Copies the elements of this Fibonacci Heap to an array in the order in which they are to be removed (basically sorted by their priorities) without removing them from this Fibonacci Heap.
member.returns: An array of the elements in this Fibonacci Heap, sorted by the order in which they are to be removed from this Fibonacci Heap.
member.remarks: Be aware that this function works by creating a "clone" of this Fibonacci Heap that takes up as much memory as it does, and then repeatedly removing elements from that "clone" and adding them to the returned array, so this function is both processor and memory intensive.

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.FibonacciNode`2.Heap.DestroyToArray(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Copies the elements of this Fibonacci Heap to an array in the order in which they are to be removed (basically sorted by their priorities) by repeatedly removing them from this Fibonacci Heap until it is empty.
member.param: If true, this function re-adds every element it removed from this Fibonacci Heap to create the returned array.
member.returns: An array of the elements in this Fibonacci Heap, sorted by the order in which they were removed from this Fibonacci Heap.
member.remarks: Be aware that this function works by repeatedly removing elements from this Fibonacci Heap until it is empty and then adding them to the returned array, which basically "destroys" this Fibonacci Heap in the process.

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.FibonacciNode`2.Heap.ToUnsortedArray
member.summary: Copies the elements of this Fibonacci Heap to an array in the order in which they are stored in its internal list of trees, which might not be the order in which they are to be removed.
member.returns: An unsorted array of the elements in this Fibonacci Heap.

remarks.para: This is a quick and clean function for creating an array of all the elements of this Fibonacci Heap without altering it. This function is much less processor and memory intensive than both and .

The only catch is that the elements in the returned array might not be in the order in which they would be removed from this heap. However, that could be easily fixed by just sorting the elements of the returned array by their keys using this heap's and then reversing it if this heap's is instead of .

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.FibonacciNode`2.Heap.GetEnumerator
member.summary: Creates a new "non-destructive" instance which enumerates the elements of this Fibonacci Heap without removing them.
member.returns: A new that enumerates the elements of this Fibonacci Heap without altering it.
member.remarks: Be aware that the returned by this function operates by removing elements from a "clone" of this Fibonacci Heap in order to keep it unaltered. This "clone" takes up as much memory as this Fibonacci Heap, and the act of creating it takes additional processing time.

member.name: M:GraphForms.Algorithms.Collections.FibonacciNode`2.Heap.GetDestructiveEnumerator
member.summary: Creates a new "destructive" instance which enumerates the elements of this Fibonacci Heap by repeatedly removing them.
member.returns: A new that enumerates the elements of this Fibonacci Heap by emptying it.
member.remarks: Be aware the the returned by this function operates by repeatedly removing elements from this Fibonacci Heap until it is empty, which makes it a one use only enumerator that basically "destroys" this Fibonacci Heap.

member.returns: A string that is a visualization (when monospaced) of the internal tree list data structure of this Fibonacci Heap.

member.summary: The comparer used to prioritize the elements in this Fibonacci Heap by determining whether the of one element is higher than, lower than, or equal to that of another element.

member.summary: If is found within this , it is replaced with , but only if isn't already contained in this .
member.param: The instance to be replaced with .
The instance to replace .

remarks.para: This function's main purpose is to obviate the task of otherwise having to meticulously replace every single instance connecting to the rest of this graph with new instances connecting to the same instances is connected to, since using or any related function also removes all of the node's connections.

However, in order to do this, this function relies heavily on the implementation of the function in the class to create replacement connections. So, ensure that function is properly implemented before using this function in order to avoid erraneous results.
